div.p: Modeling the Evolution of Degree Correlation in Scale-Free Topology Generators Modeling the Evolution of Degree Correlation Modeling the Evolution of Degree Correlation in Scalein Scale--Free Topology Generators Free Topology Generators
Joint work with Xiliang Liu and Dmitri Loguinov Internet Research Lab Computer Science Department Texas A&M University
Topology modeling is an inter-disciplinary topic Computer networks, social/biological/physics systems
Its goal is to explain how real networks have come into being To develop random graph models that capture the
In the context of computer networks, these models are useful for performance evaluations Routing delay, resilience, load balancing, etc.
Background Metrics Background Background Metrics Metrics Metrics of interest
Main: degree distribution, assortativity and clustering coefficients
Degree correlation of level k is the joint degree distribution of k adjacent nodes
Previous work (Mahadevan 2006) demonstrates that up to 3-level degree correlation suffices to characterize most of existing topologies
Thus, we focus on degree correlation in this talk
Background Metrics 2 Background Background Metrics 2 Metrics 2
Assume an undirected graph G = (V, E) of n nodes with degrees d1, , dn
L1) Degree distribution CDF F(x) = P (d<x) where d is the degree of a random node in V Scale-free graphs exhibit power-law degree
L2) Assortativity coefficient r(G) is the Pearson correlation coefficient of node degrees of links It indicates the tendency of high degree nodes
connecting frequently to other high degree nodes
L3) Clustering coefficient (G) quantifies how likely the neighbors of a node are to be connected
where i is individual clustering of node i
We study how r(G) and (G) change as graph size n grows This allows us to evaluate graph models in terms of
The set of nodes with degree no less than 2
The number of triangles residing on node i
Graph models GED (Chung 2002) PLRG (Aiello 2000) BA (Barabasi 1999) AB (Albert 2000) GLP (Bu 2002) HOT (Fabrikant 2002) SWT (Jin 2003) WIT (Wang 2006)
Geographic distance or wealth evolution and
Many large-scale networks show invariant degree correlation r(G) and (G) stay constant with growing n
However, many algorithms have decreasing degree correlation as n increases
No prior analysis has examined this issue in topology models Only partial results are available in the literature for 2
Goal is to study 1<<2 for popular generators
GED Basics GED GED Basics Basics
GED assigns random weights wi drawn from Pareto distribution F(x)
It then creates each link with probability pij
Next, we formalize the relationship between node weights and edge-existence probability We keep our formalization general enough so that it
can be applied in any graph G
Link Formation General DiscussionLink Formation Link Formation General DiscussionGeneral Discussion
Define (x, y) to be the probability of two nodes being connected given their weights x and y
For GED, this -function is simply given by
We next see how E[r(G)] and E[(G)] can be computed using the -function
Assortativity Coefficient - GEDAssortativity Coefficient Assortativity Coefficient -- GEDGED
For any graph, we can express E[r(G)]
Theorem 1: the expected assortativity coefficient of GED graphs is asymptotically:
E[dk] is the k-th moment of degree
Theorem 2: With Pareto distributed weights, the expected GED clustering is asymptotically:
Derivations are fairly convoluted See the paper for details
We next extend our results of GED to other degree-based models
Generic Framework EquivalenceGeneric Framework Generic Framework EquivalenceEquivalence
Assume two topology algorithms A and B With edge-existence probabilities A(x, y) and B(x, y), respectively
With the same weight distribution F(x)
We say A is asymptotically -equivalent to B if A(x, y) is upper/lower bounded by B(x, y):
where 0 < cL < 1 and cU 1 are some constants
Generic Framework Equivalence 2Generic Framework Generic Framework Equivalence 2Equivalence 2
Theorem 3: If algorithm A is -equivalent to B, then their expected correlation coefficients have the same asymptotic trends:
where cr and c are bounded by:
Non-Evolving Model PLRG NonNon--Evolving Model Evolving Model PLRG PLRG
PLRG generates wi virtual copies for node i
Then, it randomly pairs up virtual nodes to form actual links
Thus, PLRG has the same asymptotic degree correlation as GED
Evolving Model GLP Evolving Model Evolving Model GLP GLP
At each time step t, With probability p, GLP adds m new links among
existing nodes With probability 1p, it adds a new node with m new
The probability of selecting existing node i is proportional to its degree di
No weights used in GLP construction Thus, we cannot directly apply the GED analysis here
Evolving Model GLP 2Evolving Model Evolving Model GLP 2GLP 2
However, we can still use the framework by setting weight wi = di for each node i
where c1 and c2 are constants
Theorem 7: GLP is -equivalent to PLRG By transitivity, GLP is also -equivalent to GED
Evolving Model BA/ABEvolving Model Evolving Model BA/ABBA/AB
BA is the same as GLP with =2, p=1, and =0
AB without edge rewiring is GLP with = 1
Corollary 1: BA and AB without rewiring are equivalent to GED
Consider that BA has =2 and its clustering is
This result has been derived (Barabasi 1999) It is just a coproduct of our generic framework
Degree-Based Models Discussion DegreeDegree--Based Models Based Models Discussion Discussion Conclusion: all studied degree-based algorithms
become uncorrelated as n and their decay rates are given by:
SWT forms p percent of links using geographic preference and the rest using random pairing
HOT models each attachment decision as an optimization problem with two objectives Last-mile cost and reachability
WIT adjusts the number of links based on a stochastic wealth process Neighbor selection is based on random walks
We study these algorithms in simulations
We use the Internet AS-level graph as the benchmark Route-Views and RIPE
We extract E[r(G)] and E[(G)] from historical data of the BGP graph observed during the last 7 years The graph size increases from 4,000 to 23,000 nodes
The data shows E[r(G)] and E[(G)] of the Internet do not change much over the years
Next, we compare the studied models
We developed an analytical framework for modeling degree-based algorithms We found that all studied degree-based methods
Our simulations showed that some of the studied link-based algorithms were capable of keeping E[r(G)] and E[(G)] time-invariant
Future work Extension to other degree-based methods Analysis of link-based models Higher-order degree correlation
